page.title: 02RIVER TWEED SALMON FISHING
page.content: Method: The fishing of the river TWEED is done from fishing shiels.Nets are rowed out in a circle and are then winched in.When the fish are caught they are hit with a stick.They are then taken to an ice house until the end of the day.The number of salmon caught in 1984 was 18,478.Numbers have declined through the 1970's due partly to a fungal disease and partly to increased poaching. The fishing season starts on Feb.14 and ends on Sept.14 each year.Fish run up river on the incoming tide.Each day's fishing depends on tide times. Downstream of the fishing area,each shiel has a look-out point to spot fish running up-river.The shiel has bunks and a fireplace and is now supplied with electricity.Night fishing can go on by floodlight.Each shiel employs four men.
